text: J. D. McCarty (August 28, 1916 - December 30, 1980) was Speaker of the Oklahoma House of Representatives, serving three consecutive terms. The Democratic party, to which he belonged, had already named him as its nominee for a fourth term when he lost his reelection bid to Representative Vondel Smith in the 1966 election. "Former Oklahoma House Speaker J.D. McCarty dead." UPI Archives. January 1, 1981. Accessed August 29, 2018. In 1967, he was indicted and convicted for Federal income tax evasion. Reportedly he had failed to report the receipt of $12,000 in bribes. He was sentenced to three years' imprisonment, which he served in the Texarkana Federal Correctional Institution, where he completed his sentence in June of 1969. ==Biography== McCarty attended Oklahoma University, where he majored in economics and government. He also worked for the Daily Oklahoman at night, while attending classes during the day. In World War II, he served in the U.S. Navy in the South Pacific. He was first elected to the House in 1940. By the time he rose to the speakership in 1960, the Tulsa World called him, "...the most powerful person in the legislature." The World also said that some political observers in the state said that he was the most powerful speaker in the state's history."Knowing the territory paid off for McCarty." Tulsa World. September 29, 1992. Accessed December 16, 2018. ==Family== The parents of J. D. McCarty were Edward B.(1889–1971) and Cora L. McCarty (1899–1984). A sister, Ethel L. Chuculate (nee McCarty (1921-2003) survived him. He married Bessie M. McCarty (1938-1976), and they had two children, Michael (1940-2010) and Patricia (1941-2013). According to the Find-a grave website relatives, all of these are buried in Resthaven Gardens Cemetery, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma."J D McCarty." Find a Grave. Accessed December, 19, 2018. Patricia was cremated and her ashes spread in the foothills of Roosevelt Lake in AZ on Easter Day 2014. ==Notes== == References == Category:1930 births Category:1980 deaths Category:University of Oklahoma alumni Category:Oklahoma Democrats Category:People from Oklahoma City Category:Oklahoma politicians convicted of crimes Category:American naval personnel of World War II Category:Speakers of the Oklahoma House of Representatives
